text:
Example

To go with the package touching forbidden internal, those abuses of internals lead to bugs.
When people have tried to help fix that he's been pretty rude to them.

When it's come up that the the abuses of the internals make certain ways of building on top of his work give incorrect results his response has boiled down to "people shouldn't be making advanced use of my package or extending it. If they need that they should pay me as a consultant and I will do that".
Which to be fair: noone has a right to having a open source  we fix bugs for free. But the way it was said doesn't come off well. Particularly combined with earlier points about not accepting help graciously, inclines me not to want to go near the package.

(These are not the things that got him banned. he has been socially "difficult" beyond these things.)

text: Without commenting on what form it should take, I agree a caveat is needed.  There are purely technical points here that have nothing to do with anything social/political: the package is replete with dubious and sometimes downright bizarre uses of Julia internals.  At some point it was explained quite carefully to the author why this should not be done ,and many people were quite enthusiastic about helping fix it so that it does not risk failing spectacularly, but the author rebuffed this.  It was a pretty bizarre reaction for someone to have to a bunch of people who are excited about and interested in their work

text: I still don't understand how could it be possible to have support any kind of nontrivial higher-order tensor with any claims to differential geometry without basing it on charts, atlases and bases, despite working on it on and off for almost a year. Documentation of Grassmann.jl doesn't mention charts at all. chakralava has opened an issue about interoperability with Manifolds.jl ecosystem some time ago ( <https://github.com/JuliaManifolds/ManifoldsBase.jl/issues/4> ) but didn't answer the most basic usage questions. Which is a shame because now I have to do tensor fields myself.

text:
The package itself is, as pointed out, not reliable in general. However I find geometric algebra, the mathematical concept being implemented by the package, very exciting. It brings little in terms of new mathematical results, but brings a ton of insight related to various branches of mathematics. It is one of those unifying theories that just simplify a lot of stuff and I personally learned a lot from it. Stuff like differential geometry, spacetime physics and weird geometries are closely related in this language. It's not very popular at the moment, but I hope it will be more developed/used in the future.
But you should learn about that stuff from other sources than this package, for sure.

text:
Thank you everyone
The package does look very interesting, but It also seems to be quite unstable.
Many of the given examples in the docs crash.
The comments about the behavior of the maintainer, and there idiosyncratic use of Julia internals are also appreciated, IMO Soft ware is inherently social.
I was very excited about having high performance and general geometric algebra constructs at my figure tips.
That enthusiasm has now been tempered but I will none the less attempt to get a grip on the basic functionality of the library in the hope that future efforts in this direction become taken up by the community
